[INST] Explain the concept of cogging torque. [/INST] Cogging torque is the torque that is applied to a rotating device when the device experiences resistance from the teeth of the gears that are connected to the device. Cogging torque occurs due to the reaction force generated when the teeth of the gear drive mesh. This force pushes against each other, resulting in a drag force that is transmitted from the gears to the shaft. The magnitude of the cogging torque can vary depending on the size and number of teeth, as well as the gear's material and design. Cogging torque is undesirable in most motorized applications, as it can lead to loss of efficiency. To reduce cogging torque, gear designs are often symmetrical or have certain tooth profiles which reduce the force of contact between the teeth when they come into contact with each other.

[INST] Explain the concept of a bubble sort algorithm to a non-technical audience. [/INST] Imagine all your friends put their name and phone number on a strip of paper, and all those strips were placed into a bag and mixed around. You want a list of all these contacts, but you need them in alphabetical order to be useful. Here's how to use a bubble sort to do that:
1) Lay all the names out left-to-right. 
2) Start at the farthest left strip. Compare it to the strip on its right. If the name is later in the alphabet than the name of its righthand neighbor, swap their places.
3) Now look at the second-from-the-left strip (this might be the same strip again, if it just swapped places). Compare its name to its righthand neighbor just like before. Swap them if necessary.
4) Continue this process until you reach the farthest right strip. You now know that the farthest right strip has the name of the person latest in the alphabet. By moving through and swapping as necessary, you 'bubbled up' the latest-in-alphabet name, which is where the name bubble sort comes from.
5) Now return to the farthest left, and do the same process again, but this time you can stop at the second-from-right-most strip because you already know it's the latest-in-alphabet name.
6) Again, back to the far left strip, repeat the process, and stop at the third-from-right-most strip.
